body.p:
His Excellency Govr Thos. E Bramlette
Dear Sir
I called at your office to-day & left for your consideration, the Petition of Capt. Edwin Terrell of the Independent Ky Scouts.

I hope you will grant the prayer of his petition. He is one of the bravest men I ever saw, & has done more to rid Kentucky of Guerrillas than any man I have heard of. The fact is, his little band have been more effective in this service, than some Brigades of Cavalry. His head quarters were in Shelbyville & they gave our town & county protection which we could not have obtained from any other source.

The Hercules Walker spoken of in his petition, is the man who killed the Hills a few years ago in Jefferson County -- The same Hills who figured with the Evans in Garrard County. Walker has been charged with about a half a dozen murders in his day.

I learn that Genl Palmer
excused Terrell for killing Walker.
I have no personal knowledge of the facts about the killing of Ennis Wooten -- but have heard it from one of Terrells band, stated even more favorably to Terrell, than he states it in his petition.
I learn from undoubted authority, that Wooten was a noisy rebel from the commencement of the troubles.

Whether Terrell was justifiable, by strict law or not, in killing those two men, I do not pretend to assert. But I do say, that he has rendered such services to the state as to entitle him to some reward, and none would be more suitable to him than a free pardon for those two acts, and I hope you will grant the pardon without delay, as I most certainly would, if I were acting in your place.

This application is made by me without fee or reward, or the hope or promise thereof, made simply because I feel grateful to the man who has done such
valuable services to the state.

Shelby Cir Ct
